loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng S. is 58 and is married. She lives with her husband and six children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia: an area known for being the most populated city in the country. She and her husband sell coffee and breakfast for an income of about USD 6.5 per day.  


S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more food supplements to expand her business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. 


S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy more food supplements

loans.name: Zahera

texts.en:
Zahera N. is a young woman from Jenin, a city in North Palestine. Zahera is the mother of two sons, ages three years and one and a half years old. Zahera's husband, Ahmad, is a disk jockey for parties and weddings in Jenin.

Zahera opened her own business -- a headscarf (hijab) store -- two years ago. Zahera sells headscarves and accessories for headscarves, The store is located in the city center of Jenin and has regular customers. The store is prospering over time and Zahera wants to respond to the demand by providing a larger variety of accessories for hijabi women (women who wear a headscarf) and other items that they request. Therefore, she took a $1000 loan from FATEN.

In the photograph, her husband, Ahmad, appears in Zahera's store, because she doesn't want her picture to be published online.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence L. is from the village of Brgy.Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Florence owns and operates a motorcycle transport business. Florence has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Florence joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florence is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Florence from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Vicky's Group

texts.en:
Vicky L. is from the town of Macabacle, Concepcion, Tarlac. She is 26 years old and the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Vicky is married and has 3 very young children. She owns and operates a transportation business, providing motorcycle transport services in the local community. Vicky has been involved in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Vicky joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vicky is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a business vehicle. This will be the first loan taken out by Vicky from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle

loans.name: Mamlakathon Tursinova Group

texts.ru:
Мамлакатхон, 60 лет. Ее супруг работает директором школы. У нее 5 детей: с ней проживают сын, невестка, младший сын и 2 внучки. Старший сын находится на заработках в РФ, невестка домохозяйка - присматривает за детьми, младший сын работает мясником. Клиент занимается розничной торговлей мяса. Бизнес был начат 7 лет назад. На кредит она планирует закуп коровы, для реализации мяса и увеличить товарооборот.

Рахимахон, 51, замужем. Супруг работает парикмахером. У нее двое детей: Дочку выдала замуж, сын работает в Казахстане пекарем. Клиент занята животноводством: откорм и разведения КРС.Также занимается сбором и реализацией ысырык (растение). Ысырык она распределяет по торговым точкам. На кредит клиент планирует закупить КРС.

Жумахан, вдова. У нее 5 детей. Она вместе с сыном занимаются торговлей овощей и фруктов. На кредит планирует увеличить товарообарот в виде овощей.

Розияхон, 20, не замужем. Она проживает вместе со своими родителями. У них есть собственный земельный надел, где они выращивают растения и культуры. На кредит она планирует закуп минерального удобрения и сделать культивацию хлопка.

Эктиборхон 48 лет. Ее супруг работает водителем маршрутки. Самая младшая дочь учится в 11 классе, остальных дочерей она выдал замуж. Клиент занимается животноводством, откорм и разведение МРС.'Цель кредита - закуп МРС для разведения.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Mamlakathon is 60 years old. Her husband works as a school principal. She has 5 children. Her son, daughter-in-law and 2 granddaughters live with her. The oldest son works in the Russian Federation, daughter-in-law is a homemaker, who looks after the children, and the youngest son works as a butcher. The client is involved in retail sales of meat. Mamlakathon started the business 7 years ago. She plans to use the loan to buy a cow for meat sale and to increase product turnover. Rahimahon is 51 years old, married. Her husband works as a barber. She has two children. The daughter is married, and the son works as a baker in Kazakhstan. The client is involved in animal husbandry – fattening and breeding of cattle. She is also involved in picking and selling the ysyryk plant. She distributes this plant among retail outlets. Rahimahon plans to use this loan to buy cattle. Jumahan is a widow and has 5 children. Together with her son, she is involved in sales of vegetables and fruits. She plans to use the loan to increase product turnover for vegetables. Roziyahon is 20 years old, single. She lives together with her parents. They own a plot of land, where they grow plants and crops. She plans to use this loan to buy mineral fertilizers and cultivate cotton. Ektiborhon is 48 years old. Her husband works as a shuttle bus driver. The youngest daughter attends 11th grade, and the rest of the daughters are married. The client is involved in animal husbandry, fattening and breeding small livestock. The goal of the loan is a purchase of small livestock for breeding.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Burmabubu's Group

texts.en:
Burmabubu M. is the leader of this group. She is 51 and married. Her husband is a school teacher. Burmabubu has raised five children: three sons and two daughters. Her daughters are married and have, therefore, moved out. The tradition in Krygyzstan is that when a woman marries a man she leaves her parents' house to live with her new husband's family—unless they have enough money to get a place of their own. Burmabubu's sons have also left home to work in Bishkek. 


Burmabubu has been farming, fattening and reselling cattle for 30 years. Her husband helps her in this activity, even though teaching takes up most of his time. In this way they are able to make an additional 1700 soms ($37) a month. This made it possible for Burmabubu to build a house and contribute to the marriage of her daughters. With the loan, she will buy calves to increase the number of their cattle. In the future, Burmabubu plans to save money and contribute to her sons' weddings.

Damira B. is 59 and is married. She has three sons and three daughters. In order to make money, Damira and her husband have been fattening and reselling cattle for 30 years. In this way, they earn 6,000 soms ($130.74) per month. Damira started this business activity with an initial investment of 2,800 soms ($61).  Now she is applying for a loan to purchase calves. 

Dariya K. is 41 and is divorced. She has four sons. The younger son works in Bishkek while the others help Dariya with housework. In order to make money, Dariya fattens and resells cattle. She also sells milk. She makes 11,700 soms ($254.96) a month. Dariya wants to get a loan to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock.

Orozgul M. is 47 and is married. She has two daughters and a son. The older daughter works in Bishkek while the others are students. 30 years ago, Orozgul inherited a cow. Therefore she sells milk and resells cattle. She makes 3,000 soms ($65.37) a month. With the loan, Orozgul plans to buy cement for the construction of the shed.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase calves to increase her cattle population

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen P. is from the town of Sta. Rita, Concepcion, Tarlac. She is 36 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Aileen owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily fish balls and other dimsums, to the local community. Aileen has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Aileen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aileen is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Aileen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale

loans.name: Bou

texts.en:
Bou S. is a 44-year-old widow. She lives with her two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia: an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She and her children sell groceries and snacks at home for an income of about USD 5 per day.  


S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,100 to purchase pigs to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Chien

texts.en: Mr. V. is a 26-year-old husband and father. He currently owns a motorcycle with a trailer attached that he uses to pick up passengers for a fee, and  typically earns $5 a day. He has another financial earner in his wife who works sewing clothes in the garment factory. The couple has given birth to a young child who attends school and is under their care. V. complaints that his daily life is not easy because his old house often needs repairs. In order to help solve this problem, V. is applying for a loan to purchase building materials to replace the broken parts of his house.

loans.use: To purchase housing materials

loans.name: Ty

texts.en: Ty T. N. was born in 1956. She lives with her husband and three children in Dong Anh town. She has a store at home. She sells beer, fruit and other items. Her husband is a bricklayer. They have a monthly income of about $280. Mrs Ly has a participated in SEDA since 2006 and repays punctually. She has to raise her children, so she always tries to work hard. She likes repaying loans weekly because she can save money. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to invest in her store.

loans.use: to invest in her store.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda M. is from the town of Sta. Maria, Concepcion, Tarlac. She is 27 years old. Rosalinda is married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns and operates a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosalinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding poultry. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Roselyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase breeding poultry

loans.name: Ha

texts.en: Ha V. L. was born in 1976. She is married with two children (a daughter and a son) who are still very young. She is a tailor for a garment export company. Besides that, she breeds pigs. Her husband is a bricklayer. He has a monthly income of about $167 and hers is about $100. Mrs Ha has  participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to repair her house.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Cuc

texts.en: Cuc T. T. N. was born in 1977. She lives with her husband and three children who go to school. She has a participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. She and her husband sell seafood in the market. They have a monthly income of about $335. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to expand her business.

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Nuth

texts.en: Nuth N., 57, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a farmer and earns an income of about $2 per day. Her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning an income of $1 per day to help cover the family expenses.  N. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Alona has been engaged in her business for more than eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Alona joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Lun T., 52, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a tailor and earns an income of about $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  T. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a mechanical plow. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. loans.name: Chhouk

texts.en:
S. is a 58-year-old widow and mother. She has four children: three are married and one is single. 

To earn a living, she owns a few rooms that she rents to people for a monthly fee. In this way, S. is able to generate an income to help control her family’s financial problems. She currently has other financial earners in her children who are employed at a various occupations.  

S. finds it hard to travel anywhere because she doesn’t own a vehicle. She has always hired a taxi for transportation. She wants to eliminate this expense by asking for a loan from Kiva’s project partner, HKL, to be used to purchase a new motorcycle so that she can travel without paying for a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S., 67, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She and her husband produce hammocks for an income of about $1 each per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a generator to start a new business of recharging batteries. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a generator

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina T. is from the village of Magalalag, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 42 years old. Adelina is married and has six infant-aged children. To make a living, Adelina operates a family member's business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Adelina has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2009, Adelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Adelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Nhoem

texts.en: Mrs. Nhoem A., a 59-year-old resident of a rural commune in Phnom Penh City, works as a local tailor from home, a job she started in 2006. She was married many years ago to MA. Chorn, who is an advisor in a pagoda. The couple has four single children, and one who is married and lives separately. Two of her children who are employed contribute a little income to help with the family expenses. Nhoem A. sews silk clothes which people like to wear A. ceremonies. Recently, she is lacking some raw materials she needs to continue her sewing services. This is why she has decided to ask for a loan of $500 from Kiva.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials.

loans.name: Maria

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Maria has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,500 whenever she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2005, Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. Maria is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Ireneo

texts.en:
Ireneo M. is from the village of Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 60 years old and widowed with three adult children. To make a living, Ireneo has a butcher's shop selling a variety of meats in the local community. He has been in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Ireneo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ireneo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ireneo is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Ireneo from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Chheun

texts.en:
Mr. Chheun V. is a 37-year-old fisherman and father, blessed with five children, all of whom are attending the public high school. In addition to his fishing business, he uses his old motorcycle to deliver passers-by around the community for a fee. His wife, Chea Khan, 38, is a homemaker who cooks delicious meals for the family. 

Chheun V. says he can’t catch many fish because his fishing equipment is not good enough to sustain his business. Thus, he is looking for assistance to be used to buy a boat, nets and traps to better serve him in his fishing activities.

loans.use: To buy a boat, nets and traps.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocely P., from the village of Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, is 49 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Jocely owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 2400 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jocely joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 25000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Jocely's fourth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
When she was newly married, C. began to sell food that she prepared at home and sold in front of the garment factory. She is the mother of five young children, two of whom are employed as sewing laborers. Additionally, her husband works in the construction field.

C. says that the current income she and her husband earn is not adequate to serve them. She wants to earn extra proceeds by investing in a new trade, but she doesn’t have the money to do so. She is therefore applying for a loan to use as capital to begin selling fresh fish in the market.

loans.use: To begin selling fresh fish in the market

loans.name: Evangeline Banez Group

texts.en:
Evangeline B., from the village of Tupan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, is the 41-year-old leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Evangeline Banez Group.

Evangeline, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 900 PHP a month.

In 2007, Evangeline joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC that was used to to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Evangeline's sixth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma G. owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 33 years old, married and has three small children. They are from the village of Magalalag, Enrile, Cagayan. Emma has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. Emma says that through the business she is able to meet the daily needs of her family. In 2005, Emma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en: Baktygul O. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married and her husband works as an electrical repairman. She has raised three sons and two daughters. The older son lives with his grandparents and helps them with their housework. The second son works in Karakol at a heat-electro power station. The older daughter is married and lives in Bishkek with her family. Seventeen years ago, with an initial investment of 1,000 soms, Baktygul began to sell convenience goods at the market. Her younger daughter and son help her with this activity. This business made it possible for her to pay for her children's education and she also bought a truck. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase hosiery (socks, stockings, tights) to sell. In the autumn, Baktygul plans to get another loan, a larger one, to buy apples in order to sell them in the winter and make good money. Zhanylkan A. is 52 and is a widow. She has raised six sons and a daughter. Three sons are married and live separately in Bishkek with their families. The younger daughter is a student, and Zhanylkan’s three other sons help Zhanylkan with housework. In 1994 Zhanylkan sold potato dumplings. Then she saved some money and began to sell foodstuffs that were more profitable. Now she makes 5,000 soms a month. With the money received from this loan, Zhanylkan will purchase 100 kg of sugar and several kinds of macaroni. Sabira K. is 55 and is a widow. She raised eight children: two daughters are married and live separately with their families; the other children help Sabira with housework. In 1998 Sabira's husband died and, to make money, she started to sell foodstuffs at the market. Then her friends advised her to sell meat in order to make more money. Now she sells meat in her own pavilion and, in this way, she makes 4,000 soms a month. Sabira wants to get a loan to purchase sheep to sell. Suyumkan A. is 54 and is a widow. She raised two daughters and a son. Her son works in Kemin and he lives there with his family. The daughters are students; when they are free, they help their mom to sell meat. With money received from the loan, Suyumkan will purchase five sheep to sell. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase hosiery to sell

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia Paloma is a business-minded woman and a very good leader of the ASHI center. In spite of being a widow, her ability to raise her two children, ages 15 and 21 years old, by maintaining a small buy-and-sell vegetable business inspires her fellow women members to enhance their own productivity. Aside from supporting her children, Nelia also supports her 92-year-old mother who lives with her. 

Loans Nelia obtained through ASHI are a great source of financial assistance to sustain and grow her business. She displays excellent performance in repayment and attendance at weekly ASHI center meetings. The profit she earns from selling vegetables to people in her village and at the market provides her family with things they basically need every day. Nelia is looking forward to the day her business will become sustainable and profitable, so she can build a savings fund in preparation for the education of her youngest child from college through to graduation and a career in the future.

loans.use: To purchase large volumes of vegetables for selling

loans.name: Bit

texts.en:
Mrs. Bit C. is a 37-year-old married woman and mother. She works as a cleaner in a small restaurant located near her house and earns a suitable salary to help control all her family’s financial problems. She has another financial earner in her husband who is a watering connector who works with her in the same restaurant, earning a suitable monthly salary. This couple helps each other in order to generate money to support their two school-aged kids.

Bit C. finds it hard traveling to work or anywhere else because she has no vehicle for her transportation needs. She hopes to own a vehicle by looking for a loan to buy an old motorcycle to provide transportation for her family.

Mrs. Bit C. was busy when the photo taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle to provide transportation for her family

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios M. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 58 years old. Remedios is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Remedios operates a business venture in the services sector. The main source of income for the business comes from providing vehicle-repair services to local community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Ung

texts.en:
Ung L. N. was born in 1980 and lives with his parents. His family has a bicycle repair shop and he and his father work there. His mother is a tailor who makes gloves. They have a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamese dongs (VND).

Since 2009 Ung L. N. has participated in SEDA and has repaid punctually. For this loan, he wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to expand his bicycle repair shop.

loans.use: To expand his bicycle repair shop

loans.name: Carmelita Acal Group

texts.en:
Carmelita A. is from the village of Mangidkid. She is 53 years old. Carmelita is the group leader of a 2-member group taking out a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Carmelita is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 21st loan taken out by Carmelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Rosalia Tagab Group

texts.en:
Rosalia T. is from the village of Mangidkid. She is 68 years old. Rosalia is the group leader of a 2-member group taking out a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rosalia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalia raises livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Rosalia has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Rosalia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Rosalia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 18th loan taken out by Rosalia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her livestock business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a single mother of three children and all her children go to school. Fatuma doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Owino selling second hand clothes and sells to all categories of people.  Fatuma has been in this business for six years, selling at retail and wholesale. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Fatuma doesn’t have any side business. She uses public transport to and from home to her place of work in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Fatuma buys from the very market where she works.  She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and thieves.  She aspires to see her business grow big and start selling at wholesale only. Fatuma decided to work with MCDT because she wanted to get more money for her business.  She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she stays with eight people and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Tolib

texts.ru: Кодиров Толиб проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 31 год. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Образование высшее, программист. Работает по профессии в ЗАО ТК - мобайл. Кроме того у него интернет кафе. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для обновления компьютеров.
texts.en:
Tolib K. lives in the city of Dushanbe. He is 31 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. Tolib has a higher education as a programmer. He works in his profession at ZAO TK - mobile. Besides this work, he has an internet cafe. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. Tolib is requesting this loan in order to refresh the computers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refreshing computers

loans.name: Umoja Wa Kinamama Group

texts.fr:
Adidja N.  est une commerçante âgée de 69ans qui habite la Commune de Buyenzi en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de produits vivriers entre autres,les legumes,le riz,le haricot et les fruits au marche de Ruvumera situe au quartier Buyenzi a Bujumbura. C’est un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 16 ans alors qu’elle tenait une cafeteria. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’au niveau du primaire . Son époux, Djumaine M., est un chauffeur. Elle arrive au 8e cycle avec le crédit de Turame. 

Elle a 6 enfants dont 5 étudient a l’école secondaire.

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour acheter de plus grandes quantités de produits vivriers à revendre aux clients ; ce qui lui permettra d’acquérir une plus grande capacité de générer du bénéfice pour faire ses épargnes et accroitre son business dans l’espoir de devenir une commerçante grossiste. Elle a l’espoir que ses enfants finiront les études avec succès et  être capables de mener une vie meilleure. Elle a toujours préfère le crédit Turame aux autres institutions financières car les conditions d’accès et de remboursement lui sont plus faciles.

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Umoja wa Kinamama » qui veut dire « unité pour les mères ».
texts.en:
Adidja N. is a trader who is 69 years old and lives in the commune of Buyenzi in the municipality of Bujumura. She buys and sells food products including vegetables, rice, beans and fruit, at the market in Ruvumera, which also lies in the Buyenzi district of Bujumbura. She has been carrying out this business for the past 16 years, while she had a cafeteria before. She left school at primary school level. Her husband, Djumaine M., is a driver. She is on her eighth loan from Turame. She has six children, of whom five are at secondary school. She is requesting the Kiva loan in order to buy food products in greater quantities and resell them to her customers; this will allow her a more significant profit-generating capacity, so that she can save money and expand her business with the hope of becoming a wholesaler. She hopes that her chlidren will successfully complete their studies and be capable of leading a better life. She has always preferred borrowing from Turame rather than other financial institutions, because the access and repayment terms are easier for her. She is a member of the community group "Umoja wa Kinamama" which means "Unity for Mothers".

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase greater quantities of food products to resell to customers

loans.name: Lunida

texts.en:
Lunida C. is from the village of Aguada, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Lunida is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Lunida owns and operates an eatery. Lunida has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lunida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lunida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for additional capital for her eatery. Lunida is now requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital for her eatery. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Lunida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her eatery

loans.name: Comlan

texts.en:
Monsieur Comlan A. is 38 years old and lives in Lomé, Togo. He and his wife have one child.

Comlan sells frozen food products at a store called “Saint Esprit.” He requests his first loan of 300,000 XOF from WAGES to help him increase his merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen products to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn J. is from the village of Tubod. She is 28 years old. Jocelyn is married and has five children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a hog-raising business in the agricultural sector, raising pigs for sale. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for this activity.

In 2005, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To buy feeds and other vaccines

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam L. is from the village of Gata Daku, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Meriam is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Meriam owns and operates a photography business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing photography services to local community members. Meriam has been engaged in her business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Meriam joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Meriam from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

location.town: Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en: Kasifa is widowed with six children and only two of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members.  Kasifa sells yellow bananas in Nakawa market, one of the markets in Kampala City. She uses public transport to and from home. Kasifa buys from her place of work from delivery vans, which bring the bananas from the villages.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches and clusters of yellow bananas. Kasifa has been in this business for over 20 years and with MCDT for nine years. She pays daily market dues of 1,000/=. She works seven days a week.  Her major business challenge is that of the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She aspires to acquire a permanent business structure and to start going directly to farmers for her bananas. She decided to join MCDT because it was helping poor women. She resides in and owns a four-room house where she stays with six members. The family has no access to electricity or water. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Abiré

texts.en:
Abiré K. is 24 years old. She has a business selling baby products, home cleaning products, and beauty products. She has been in business for four years.

Abiré has requested a 200,000 CFA loan from WAGES to purchase more baby diapers and beauty products. This is her first loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more baby diapers and beauty products

loans.name: Minh

texts.en:
Minh V. P. was born in 1981 and lives in Dong Anh town with his wife and their two children who are still young. He is a bricklayer and his wife earns an income as a worker in a factory. His family has a monthly income of about 4,500,000 Vietnamese dongs (VND).

Minh V. P. has a participated in SEDA since 2006 and has repaid punctually. Now, he wants to have more tools for his business. So, for this loan, he needs 8,066,000 VND to buy the tools.

loans.use: To buy tools for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of petrol

loans.name: Tseveldulam

texts.en:
Tseveldulam D. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and son in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger (the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). They have been living together in their current home for ten years. Her 20-year-old son is a university student.

Tseveldulam operates a meat-retailing business. She has been operating her business since 2000 and has steadily expanded her business over the past ten years. Her main customers are local residents who live in the center of her province.

Tseveldulam purchases meat from the countryside at wholesales prices to retail to her customers. In addition, she sells to the wholesalers as well. She is an enthusiastic person. She says, “Now, the most important thing to me is to be financially able to pay my child's university tuition fees until he graduates. In addition, I have a goal to build a house for my family.”

Tseveldulam is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of meat at wholesale prices in order to sell it to her many customers.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of meat at wholesale prices

loans.name: Lynn

texts.en:
Mrs. Lynn A. is from the barangay of P-Madanihon, Tinago, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Lynn is married and blessed with two children, one at school age and the other still an infant. To make a living, she is presently engaged in a food business, particularly in chicken barbecue and a little eatery. She’s engaged in this kind business for more than three years already and earned approximately 12,000 PHP gross a month from this chicken barbecue and little eatery business.

In 2008, Lynn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lynn is now requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP as her third loan availment, which will be used to add capital in her existing chicken barbecue and little eatery business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs and savings for future use, especially for her child’s education, loan repayments and possible business expansions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for her chicken barbecue and little eatery business

location.town: P Madanihon, Tinago, Ozamiz City, Mindanao

loans.name: Abdull Qayum

texts.en: Abdull Qayum son of M. Y. is 45 years old, married and the father of four children. He lives in district 8th of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a whole sales store (the materials of shoe-making) in the city of Kabul. He brings all the tools for his store from Pakistan and he is involved in this business for more then one year. He and all the family members benefit from his income. He wants to expand his business and to attract more clients, so he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani. He is happy that he has the chance to progress as soon as possible.

loans.use: To expand his business and to attract more clients.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn G. is from the village of Lumipac. She is 41 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a business in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the selling of assorted dry goods in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stocks. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Marilyn from PMPC.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Akosiwa Enyonam

texts.en:
Madame Akosiwa Enyonam A. owns a general store in the Kegue region of Lomé, Togo. She is 24 years old and has one child. Her husband is an architect.

Akosiwa has been in business for only a year and this will be her first loan from WAGES. She has requested 150,000 CFA to purchase all sorts of goods for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothes to resell

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is 38 years old. He is married and has four children aged between 3½ and 19 years, all of whom are currently attending school.

Henry is a farmer in Eastern Kenya near Nkubu town. He has been farming for twenty-five years and he sells his bananas to the middlemen/brokers who later sell them to the local market. He also earns income from his current employment as a mason. His main challenges in farming are diseases which affects his farm produce.

Henry successfully completed his first loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES 20,000 which he used to start a poultry project. He has requested this new loan from Juhudi for KES 36,400 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income generated from this loan will assist him in educating his children.

Henry intends to expand his dairy farming by buying more cows and constructing a bigger zero-grazing shed (raising improved breeds of livestock under confined conditions in order to make better use of limited land area, feed and organic resources). He also plans to venture into a taxi business.

Henry says "Juhudi Kilimo loans are helping people to view farming as a business".

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.ru: Ходжаев Хусейн проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, занимается растениеводством. Сын, строитель. Сам Хусейн имеет высшее образование. Преподает в средней школе. Одновременно занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en:
Huseyn H. lives in the Yavan district. He is 48 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is involved in agriculture. His son is a construction worker. Huseyn has a higher education and teaches at a secondary school. Concurrently, he is involved in agriculture. He has a plot of land by his house, where he sows wheat. He has been involved in this business for over 10 years. Huseyn is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Juvenaray

texts.en:
Juvenaray is 44 years old and is the married father of three children, 1½, 4 and 10 years old. Two of the children are attending school.

Juvenaray is a farmer in Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya where he has been farming for nine years. His main product is bananas which he sells to the middlemen. He solely depends on the income from his farming activities to cater for his family needs. His biggest challenges in farming are the low prices and insufficient market for his products.

Juvenaray successfully completed his previous loan of KES 40,000 from Juhudi Kilimo and requested this loan of KES 70,000 to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will help increase the income he generates from farming, hence improving his family’s  living standard.

in five years' time, Juvenaray would like to buy another piece of land to expand his farming activities. He says "Services from Juhudi have greatly improved and the loan term is flexible compared to other organizations."

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en:
Monicah is 49 years old and is married with three children: 14, 20 and 24 years old. Her youngest child is still attending school.

Monicah is a farmer in Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. She has been farming for ten years and her main product is milk which she sells to Meru Central Sacco in Meru town. She is also a businesswoman and sells fruit in an open air market in the same area. Her main challenges in farming are pests and diseases which attack her dairy cows.

Monicah has requested this KES 45,000 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry project. The income from this loan will enable her to educate her son and build a better zero-grazing shed (to raise improved breeds of livestock under confined conditions in order to make better use of limited land area, feed and organic resources).

In future, Monicah intends to purchase one more dairy cow and plant more fruit, especially passion fruit and tomatoes. She says, "Juhudi Kilimo loans are helping farmers to boost their production".

loans.use: To expand her poultry farming

loans.name: Ariunaa

texts.en:
Ariunaa D., 40, is a widow and lives with her 13-year-old daughter in an apartment in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia.

Ariunaa operates a men’s and women’s clothing and underwear trading business at a rented counter at a local market. She has been operating her business since 1997, and has steadily expanded her business over the past thirteen years. She purchases her products 1-2 times a month, depending on her product sales. Since she started her business, her family's living conditions have been improving.

Ariunaa has good communication skills and has many plans for the future. She says, “I have a goal to save money from now to be financially able to pay my daughter's university tuition fees after she graduates from high school. In addition, I will work hard and use all of my abilities in order to purchase an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, because my daughter will study there in university.”

Ariunaa is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a variety of summer clothing from Ereen, a Chinese border town, to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of summer clothing

loans.name: Latifa Shebirghani Group

texts.en: Latifa is the daughter of M. R., the leader of Latifa Shebirghani group. She lives in district 8th Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has six children. She is a tailor and works hard to earn money for the completion of her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine and cloths for her business because she has lots of problems with the old machine during sewing. Besides, she wants to hire a student to support her in her business and to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and cloths for her business

loans.name: Adjete Group

texts.fr: Ce groupement est composé de 3 dames très dynamiques qui exercent dans le commerce en détail de boissons,  céréales  et charbons. Le revenu de leurs activités leur permet de faire les activités sociales et d’entraide entre elle et avec les autres femmes dans le besoin. Elles ont besoin d’agrandir leur association à travers leurs activités raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  sodabi, maïs, haricot, riz et charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This group is composed of three very dynamic women who operate a retail business selling drinks, cereals and charcoal. The income from their business enables them to take part in social and support activities both among themselves and with other women in need. They need to expand their association through their activities, hence the reason they are asking WAGES for a loan to buy sodabi, corn, beans, rice and charcoal.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy drinks, cereals, charcoal and other items

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 26 years old and married with one child, 2½ years old. He is a farmer in Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya.

Godfrey has been farming for two years and his main product is bananas which he sells to the local market. He relies solely on the income from his farming activities to cater for his family's needs. His main challenge in this business is the low price of bananas, especially during the rainy season.

Godfrey has requested this KES 46,800 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will improve his family's living standard because, with the income from selling milk, he will be able to construct a house and the family will have enough milk for consumption.

In future, Godfrey plans to acquire more cows and construct a zero-grazing shed (to raise improved breeds of livestock under confined conditions in order to make better use of limited land area, feed and organic resources). He plans to lease more banana plantation land to increase his income.

Godfrey says that Juhudi loans are repaid monthly and this gives him ample time to look for money compared to other organizations where they repay weekly. He says Juhudi is also fast in loan processing.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Chemetet

texts.en:
R. is 30 years old. She is married and has three children between 2½ and 8 years old. Two of her children are attending school.

R. is a farmer in Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. She has been farming for ten years and has two employees. Her main product is milk which she sells to the middlemen who later sell to the local market. She also earns income by selling maize to the local market. Her main challenges are the fluctuating prices of milk and lack of enough water for farming.

R. successfully completed her first loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES 30,000. She has requested this new loan of KES 40,000 from Juhudi to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will increase her family's sources of income and enable her to pay school fees for her children.

In future, R. would like to acquire quality dairy cows which can produce about 20 liters of milk per day. She appreciates the work Juhudi is doing in providing loans to small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Bahitgul

texts.en:
Bahitgul H., 23, lives with her parents and sibling in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. Her father is retired and her mother operates a meat-trading business at a market called Tirlik. Her sibling attends a local kindergarten.

Bahitgul operates a fruit and vegetable trading business at the Tirlik market. She started operating a meat-trading business with her mother in 2004 and, since that time, has been operating her fruit and vegetable trading business. She purchases her products from Taikeshken, a Chinese border town, at wholesale prices and sells them at her rented counter.

Currently, Bahitgul’s working capital is 2,000,000 tugrugs. She purchases 280,000 tugrugs worth of products once a month. Her monthly net profit is 200,000 – 300,000 tugrugs. She sells a kilogram of potatoes for 600 tugrugs, a kilogram of carrots for 1,200 tugrugs, a kilogram of apples for 2,500 tugrugs and a kilogram of yellow turnips for 800 tugrugs.

Bahitgul is an enthusiastic person and is focused on the future. She says, “To keep the fruit and vegetables fresh is a very important thing in my business. I will work hard to provide healthy vegetables to my customers.”

Bahitgul is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan to purchase a variety of fruit and vegetables at wholesales prices from Taikeshken, which is located 700 kilometers away from her town.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Messan Kwami

texts.en:
Monsieur Messan Kwami Q. sells thread, ribbons, fabrics, and other products in his home town of Lomé, Togo. He has been in business since 2003. He and his wife, who is also an entrepreneur, have four children.

Messan has requested his first loan from WAGES of 500,000 CFA to purchase more merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Ahmad Zaki

texts.en: Ahmad Zaki is the son of A. M., 20 years old and a single boy. He lives in district 2nd of Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives together with all his six family members. He has a shop where he sells car oil and tires. He is a hard-working man and tries to have a comfortable life and educated children. Ahmad wants to take an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani. Through the loan, he wants to expand his business and to buy some essential tools that can make his work easier.

loans.use: To buy some essential tools which can make his work easier

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 39 years old and married with four children between 1½ and 20 years old. Three of her children are currently attending school.

Alice is a farmer in Kitale town in Western Kenya. She has been farming for one year and has only one employee. Her main product is eggs which she sells to the local market. She also earns income from a kiosk (small shop) which she operates in the same area. Her main challenge is diseases which attack the chickens abruptly and costs a lot of money to treat. The high costs of poultry feeds is also a challenge to her.

Alice has requested this KES 30,000 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry project. The extra income generated from this loan will assist her in educating her children. In the next five years, she hopes to have purchased a pick-up which will assist her in supplying eggs to the market.

Alice says "The duration of cheque processing needs to be shortened and products diversified."

loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Zaratou

texts.fr: cette jeune femme est célibataire, afin de subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens, elle a entamé l'année dernière le commerce de produits cosmétiques, elle dresse son étalage de marchandises à la devanture de sa maison. Elle veut agrandir son étalage de marchandises, pour cette raison, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour agrandir son commerce avec divers articles de mercerie.
texts.en:
This young woman is single and, in order to meet her daily needs, started a business last year selling cosmetics. She sets up her stall in front of her house. She wants to increase the size of her stall and for this reason is requesting a loan from WAGES so she can add miscellaneous dry goods to her business.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Symon

texts.en:
Symon is 58 years old and married with six children: five adults and one teenager who is still attending school.

Symon is a farmer in Murang'a town in Central Kenya. He has been farming for over thirty years and has employed one person from the community. His main product is milk which he sells to the local market. He is also a cash-crop (a crop that is grown for profit) farmer and sells his coffee to the the local market. His biggest challenges are the unstable market and fluctuation in the price of milk.

Symon has requested this KES 63,600 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will increase his family’s income through the sale of milk and help him pay school fees for his son. In future, he would want to purchase three pure-bred cows producing between 25 and 30 liters of milk each per day.

Symon says, "Juhudi Kilimo is doing a great job and the services are efficient. With Juhudi Kilimo loans there is hope for a better future."

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a single mother of five children and four of her children go to school. Sarah doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She sells local gin to all categories of people. She buys this local gin from suppliers on Mengo Kisenyi Kafumbe Mukasa Road and those suppliers get it from the villages of Kyenjojo, Fort Portal and Kasese. Sarah doesn’t pay rent for her business because she works from her home. She wants to use this loan of 1,000,000/= to buy more jerrycans of local gin.  She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters.  She aspires to own a fully stocked bar. Sarah joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting more capital. She resides in and rents a two-room house where she stays with her children. Her monthly expenses include rent, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gIn

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira Z. is the leader of a loan group. She is 53, a widow and has raised three daughters and a son. All the daughters are married and live separately with their own families. Gulmira's son is also married. He and his family live with her. Fourteen years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms (108.95$), Gulmira started selling a traditional national drink known as "Bozo" at the local market. She then expanded her business and began selling a variety of clothing at the market. Gulmira earns 8000 soms (174.33$)a month. With money received from this new loan, Gulmira will purchase sheep for breeding. In the future Gulmira plans to expand her business, repair the house and increase the number of livestock.

Nurlanbek C. is 38, he is married and has four daughters. Two of his daughters are students and other two are preschool age. Nurlanbek's wife stays at home, takes care of their daughters and does the housework. Nurlanbek works as a repairman at the railway station. He wants to get a loan because he needs money to purchase construction materials to build a house.

Perizat S. is 24 and married. Her husband works as a prison controller. They have three sons. Alll of them are preschool aged and Perizat takes care of them. Perizat applied for the loan, because she wants to purchase sheep and breed them. 

Kattobubu S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 51 and married. She has raised three sons and two daughters. The younger son is a student. When he has free time, he helps his parents with housework.  The other children are married and live separately with their families. Kattobubu has been selling locally made beverages for fourteen years. Kattobubu makes 5200 soms (108.95$) a month and has applied for a loan in order to pay for her daughter-in-law's education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en:
Peterson is 32 years old and single. He is a hardworking farmer from Murang'a town in Central Kenya. He has been farming for 6 years and employs 2 people from the community. His main produce is french beans, which he sells to Evabest Horticultural Company in Murang'a town. 

He has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.50,000 to purchase farm supplies that will help him with growing french beans. He also intends to use KES.5,000 to purchase a bull. This loan will enable him to practice large scale farming without straining financially. His biggest challenge has been poor roads that delay transportation of products to the market. In the future, he hopes to expand his farming to cover 5 acres with an output of 5400 kgs per hectare at harvest.

He hopes to see a bright future through Juhudi loans.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Abiba

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de charbons de bois ; elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans une zone où les charbons de bois sont de bonne qualité. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail. Elle exerce ce commerce dans le quartier de Kégué à Lomé où beaucoup de personnes viennent s’approvisionner chez elle. Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2001 ; pour éviter une éventuelle rupture de stocks, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 25 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman runs a business selling charcoal. She gets her supplies from the interior of the country in an area where charcoal is of good quality. She sells at both wholesale and retail. She runs this business in the Kégué district of Lomé where many people come to buy supplies from her. She started the business in 2001. To avoid shortages in stock, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 25 bags of charcoal. She is married and has two children.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Frishta Sardar Group

texts.en: Belqis is daughter of S. Q., 52 years old and the leader of Frishta Sardar group. She is married and the mother of eight children. She lives in district 7th of Kabul, Afghanistan. Her husband has a general store and all the family members benefit from his income. She wants to take a loan for her husband's store.
