Her husband wants to expand his business and to attract more clients, so she has requested a loan for her husband. Now both are happy that they have the chance to progress as soon as possible.

loans.use: To expand his business and to attract more clients

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is 36 years old and married with 4 children, aged between 2 to 17 years old. Three of the children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Litein in the Rift Valley, Kenya. Vivian has been farming for 12 years and has managed to employ 1 person from the community. She practices mixed farming and also sells milk and tea at the local market. Her biggest challenges are lack of enough feed for her dairy cows and insufficient market for her products.

She successfully completed a previous loan for KES.40,000 from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested a new loan for KES.70,000 to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will increase the family income through the sale of milk. With the extra dairy cow the family can access larger loans and sell the calves to raise more money for family use.

She says that as a group they are able to request more loans once they clear their current loans. Vivian is grateful to Juhudi for its constant help.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Koura

texts.fr:
Madame Koura Dembélé   est âgée de 45 ans,  mariée  et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans une  famille  polygame avec son mari, ses enfants et sa coépouse à Ségou Médine (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école, elle commença tôt les activités commerciales auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années passées à côté de cette dernière, elle maîtrise les rouages du commerce notamment celui du bois de construction qu’elle mène depuis 5 ans au marché de Médine. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans le souci  de faire face à la  demande clientèle de plus en plus grandissante, elle fait recours à  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 42 mois, après 3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel  qu’elle  compte utiliser pour acheter, 3 chargements de camion en bois de construction. 
Elle s’approvisionne dans la forêt dite de la Faya, sur la route de Bamako, auprès des organisations paysannes en charge de la gestion de cette forêt.
Madame  Koura Dembélé  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de maçons,  d’entreprises de construction et de bureaux d’études.
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 120 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales et de payer ses dettes. 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Koura Dembélé, 45, is married and the mother of 5 children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her children, and her co-spouse in Ségou Médine (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school at all, she began to work at commercial activities at a young age, helping her mother who sold condiments. After working with her mother for several years, she had learned all the ins and outs of business, especially that of selling wood for construction which she has been doing for five years in the market of Médine. She has a vast clientele and is well-known. Wishing to satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she came to Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has been working for 42 months, having received three solidarity loans and two individual loans, all of which have been reimbursed. She is on her third individual loan which she plans to use to buy three truckloads of wood for construction. She gets her wood in the forest called 'de la Faya', on the road to Bamako, from rural people's organizations charged with managing this forest. Mrs. Koura Debélé sells for cash or credit to a clientele composed of masons, construction firms, and such. With this loan she hopes to make a profit of 120,000 F CFA which will be used to cover certain family expenses and pay off her debts. Her ambition is to build a residential house for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy wood for building purposes for resale

loans.name: Fidélia

texts.fr: Cette dame a appris le métier de couture. C’est pour cela qu’en 2002 elle a ouvert sa boutique de couture dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Elle est mariée à un aspirant notaire de justice. Elle est très bien connue de nombreuses clientes qui apprécient la qualité de ses services. Cette femme achète des pagnes de qualité qu’elle revend ensuite à ses clientes ; raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 15 pagnes Wax Hollandais, 20 pagnes Hitarget et bien d’autres produits. Elle est mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
This woman learned to be a seamstress. Because of this skill, she opened a sewing boutique in 2002 in the Hédzranawoé quarter of Lomé. She is married to an aspiring judicial notary. She is very well known by a number of clients who appreciate the quality of her services. This women purchases quality fabric which she then resells to clients. She is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 15 pieces of Dutch, waxed fabric, 20 pieces of Hitarget fabric, and lots of other products. She is the mother of one child.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and other sewing accessories

loans.name: Mah Pari Group

texts.en: Living with his whole family of six members in the 7th District of Kabul, Afghanistan, Shafi, the son of Q., is the 25-year-old the leader of Mah Pari group. A carpet weaver for more than 10 years, he earns sufficient money for the essential requirements of his family.  Shafi is requesting a loan in order to expand his business and purchase a new carpet frame, hoping to thereby increase his monthly income.

loans.use: To purchase a new carpet frame.

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 18 Novembre 1979 à Sikasso, Monsieur  Ousmane Samaké est marié et réside avec son épouse à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Ousmane Samaké, après avoir mené  plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié  au commerce  notamment  de la quincaillerie  il y a maintenant sept  ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ  quelques années.
Il est à son  troisième prêt individuel, après avoir correctement les  deux précédents. 
Ce  troisième  prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 40 cartons d’ampoules différentes, 25 cartons de contacteur, 10rouleaux de fil, 40 paires de réglette, 20 paquets de disjoncteur, des rouleaux de câbles. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi et Abidjan (respectivement au Mali, en Burkina Faso, au Ghana et en Côte d’Ivoire) avant de les revendre en détail.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 300 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on November 18, 1979 in Sikasso, Mr. Ousmane Samaké is married and lives with his wife in Mamassoni, one of the outlying districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the republic of Mali). After having tried out several businesses without success, Mr. Ousmane Samaké, started selling hardware seven years ago. He is much sought after by his clientele due to the good quality of his products. In order to satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso some years ago. He is on his third individual loan, after having correctly repaid the two preceding ones. This third loan will allow him to buy 40 cartons of various light bulbs, 25 cartons of switches, 10 rolls of wire, 40 pairs of terminals, 20 packets of circuit breakers and some rolls of cable. He buys his supplies in Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi and Abidjan (respectively in Mali, Burkina Faso, Ghana et Côte d’Ivoire) and then retails them. He hopes to use this loan to make a monthly profit of 300,000 F CFA which will essentially serve to grow his working capital for expenditures, contribute to covering family expenses, and pay the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various hardware items for resale

loans.name: Ayawovi

texts.en: Madame Ayawovi T., 49, has been selling maize and coal out of her home in the Kegue District of Lomé, Togo since 2000.  She and her husband, who is retired, have three children. Madame T. is requesting her first loan with WAGES in the amount of 400,000 CFA to purchase charcoal, maize, and other items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and maize

loans.name: Chimed

texts.en:
Chimed N., 35, a married father of three children, lives with his family in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic housing tent) in a rented yard. Having moved from another soum (a small village) called Olziit to their current soum four years ago, they have been residing in their present home for two years. Chimed's oldest two sons, aged 11 and 6, attend a local primary school.

Chimed has been operating an underwear and outerwear clothing trading business since 2007, having gained much experience in previous years. His sister helps him purchase his products from Ereen, a Chinese border town, and brings clothing to him. Possessed of good communication skills and focused on the future, Chimed has built a loyal customer base. He and his wife want to expand their business and build their own house in the future, so he is now requesting a loan of 1,900,000 MNT to purchase a variety of underwear and outerwear clothing for all ages.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of underwear and outerwear

loans.name: Bahtazh Akas Group

texts.en: Din M. is the son of A. S., 21 years old, a single boy and the leader of Bahtazh Akas group. He lives in district 5th of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a general store. He has been involved in this business for more than three years, where he sells different kinds of things and supports all his family members. He would like to expand his business and to buy some more materials for his shop to attract more clients. He wants to take a loan to buy all the required materials for his general shop.

loans.use: To buy all the required materials for his general shop

loans.name: Hanat

texts.en:
Hanat S., 36, lives with his wife and 11year old daughter. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). They have been living together in their current home for 20 years. His daughter, Kumis, attends a local primary school. His wife is a nurse in a local hospital. 

During the day, Hanat operates a truck transportation business. His truck is Russian and his business requires lot of fuel but the truck operates without any problems. Besides his transportation business, he also operates a carpentry business during the summer. He builds houses which take three months to complete. Hanat earns 400,000 – 800,000 MNT for per house that he builds. He is an honest and industrious person. 

Hanat would like to create his own carpentry workshop in the future. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to transport stones from the countryside in order to resell them in Ulgii soum.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for his truck

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine is married to a market vendor and they have four children who go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.   Previously was operating a ladies salon but changed her business enterprise to food vending. Currently Justine owns a banana stall in Kalerwe market, selling bananas. She has been doing this for three months.  She buys bananas from the very market where she works and she works seven days a week.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  Justine sells to all categories of people at wholesale and retail. Justine aspires to build her own house. Her business challenges include thieves and seasonality.  She decides to work with MCDT because she wanted to get timely loans. She has been with MCDT for over five years.  Justine resides in and rents a one-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of  bananas

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara A. is the leader of a loan group. She is 40 and married. Because of the high unemployment rate her husband was obligated to go to Russia in order to make some money. Gulnara has a son and two daughters. Her son is a student and the daughters are preschool age. Fourteen years ago with the initial investment of 4000 soms (87.16$) Gulnara began to sell children's wear. Now, she also sells different fruits and vegetables. In this way she makes 1500 soms (32.68$) a month. With the money received from the loan Gulnara will purchase cattle, which she plans to sell after fattening it. In the future Gulnara wants to repair her house and buy a vehicle.

Mamrasul S. is 42, he is married. His wife went to Russia to make some money. They have four children, all of them are students.  Mamrasul has been breeding and reselling cattle for thirteen years. In this way he makes 700 soms (16.34$) a month. He started this activity with the initial investment of 1500 soms (32.68$). Now he wants to get a loan to purchase more cattle. 

Guluipa T. is 37, she is married. She has four children and all of them are students. When they are free, they help Guluipa with housework. Guluipa and her husband has been breeding and reselling cattle for thirteen years. In this way she makes 1500 soms (32.68$) a month. She wants to get a loan to purchase some cattle, in order to increase the herd.

Altynai K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and married. Her husband works as a tractor driver. They have four children. All of them study at school. Thirteen years ago with the initial investment of 1800 soms (39.2$) Altynai started to breed and resell cattle. In this way she makes 1300 soms (28.32$) a month. With money received from the loan Altynai plans to buy cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Koffi

texts.en: Madame Koffi S., a 33-year-old married mother of three, has been selling charcoal and cereals out of her home in Lomé since 1998.  Well-acquainted with WAGES, Madame S. is now requesting her third loan from the organization, seeking 500,000 CFA to purchase more charcoal and cereals to sell.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and grains

loans.name: Huat

texts.en:
Huat U. is 51 years old and lives with his wife and son in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent). His son, Ahjol, attends a local secondary school and his wife, Sheker, is retired.
During the day, Huat operates an auto spare parts trading business. He purchases used cars and dismantles them to get spare parts to sell at his shop, which is located in a market called Ah-Dam. Huat has been operating his business since 2006, and has become well known in his province. His monthly profit is between 240,000 and 300,000 MNT. Huat has a great business mind and is good at making decisions. In the future, he would like to sell new spare parts in his shop. Huat is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more used cars for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more used cars for spare parts

loans.name: Noorzia Noori Group

texts.en:
This is Zabihullah son of E.. He is 27 years old and the leader of Noorzia Noori group, and a married father of three children. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a barber and has a shop in the city. He has been involved in this business for more than two years. Now he wants to buy new furniture for his shop.

Therefore, he has requested a loan. With this loan, he wants to buy three chairs for his shop. He would like to say thanks to all lenders, Kiva and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy new furniture for his shop

loans.name: C2880 Amizero Group

texts.en:
Florence is 40 years old and is married with two children who are 18 and 20 years old. She is the leader of a group called Amizero and this group is well-known in the business of selling clothes and some decorative items. This is their tenth successful year in this business and the hours of the business are from 6 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

Florence and her team are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing more attractive styles of clothes and increasing the sale and rent of decorative items. If this plan is successful, Florence and her team will hopefully earn more profits which in turn will allow them to keep reinvesting in the business for better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase different styles of clothes and more decorative items

loans.name: Adjowavi

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est lancée en 2009 dans la vente de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne à Notsé et Dapaong, deux villes situées à des dizaines de kilomètres de Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant ; et cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle exerce ce commerce dans le marché de Hédrznawoé à Lomé. Pour lancer de nouvelles commandes, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 35 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
In 2009, this woman began selling wood charcoal. She stocks up on supplies in Notsé and Dapaong, two towns situated tens of kilometers from Lomé. She is married and has one child. Her work allows her to contribute financially to her household. She works at the Hédrznawoé market in Lomé. To begin filling new orders, she is asking for a WAGES loan to purchase 35 bags of wood charcoal.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wood charcoal

loans.name: Nimata

texts.en: Madame Nimata S. is 25 years old and lives in her hometown of Lomé. She has been in business selling cosmetic products and other items in her shop since 2005. She has requested a loan of 400,000 XOF to purchase more merchandise for her store. This is her first loan from Kiva partner, WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Herman

texts.en:
Herman is 22 years old, is single, and still lives with his parents. He owns a small business selling various cosmetics products and this is his 5th year of successful operation. This business is profitable in his region because it is a big center where they need this kind of product.

Herman is organized as well as well-known. He employs one person in his business as a helper so that his business runs smoothly.

Herman is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing new products such as foodstuffs and other products which are needed in his community. This loan is very important to him because he will be able to save money from selling more products and buy his own house.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing new products such as foodstuffs and other products

loans.name: Salima Nakafeero

texts.en: Salima is widowed with six children and four of her children go to school.  Salima owns a poultry farm consisting of 300 chickens. She resides in Kawempe Division, one of Kampala city suburbs. She has been in this business for many years. She wants to use this loan to buy morebags of chicken feeds. Besides this poultry business, she also fries samosas and she owns rental rooms.  Salima sells to all categories of people at retail and wholesale. She buys chicken feeds from Mengo Kisenyi markets and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her major customers are nearby shops and people from Kalerwe.  Salima works seven days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and thieves. She aspires to see her business grow big and own 1,000 chickens.  She joined MCDT because they don’t ask for collateral before giving you a loan. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed

loans.name: Sanah

texts.en:
Sanah S., 54, is a widower who lives with his two daughters in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His youngest daughter, Amangul, is a university student.
During the day, Sanah operates a clothes trading business at a market called Tirlik, with his eldest daughter's help. He has been operating his business since 2000, and has gained significant experience in the past ten years. His eldest daughter purchases fashionable clothing for young people from Taikeshken, a Chinese border town. She purchases the items once a month, and it costs 200,000 MNT. Sanah's daily revenue is 60,000 MNT. Furthermore, his monthly profit is between 200,000 and 400,000 MNT. Sanah has built a loyal customer base because of the good selection and design of his clothing and his communication skills. Sanah is an honest person who has a great business mind. He says, “Today is today, tomorrow is tomorrow. I always try to not put off today's work to tomorrow.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory from Taikeshken for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan A., 60, is widowed and lives with her two children in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. She sells fruit and makes an income of about $5 USD per day. Her daughter produces baskets for sale, earning an income of $2.5 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.
A. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to stock more fruit in her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. A. appears in the photograph with her daughter.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to stock her store

loans.name: Arthur

texts.en:
Arthur is 41 years old, married, and has children aged between 3 and 17 years old. All of the children, except one, attend school. Arthur is a farmer from near Kitale town, Western Kenya, where he has been farming for 17 years. His main produce is tomatoes and vegetables, which he sells to the local market. Arthur is also a mason and earns income from the services he provides to the local market.
Arthur recently completed his second loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 33,000 KES. He has requested a new loan of 34,320 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will enable him to purchase a dairy cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and sale. He faces the challenge of market research and animal diseases. In future, he would like to supply his milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries.
Arthur says that the loan he has been given has helped him to be a dairy farmer and he appreciates the support he has been given by Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: Tes V., 30, is married and resides with her husband and young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of about $2 per day, while her husband sells cows, earning an income of $3.3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  V. is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase silk and rice for resale, and in the future would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy silk and rice for resale

loans.name: Leatitie

texts.en:
Leatitie is 26 years old and is married with one child who is three years old. Leatitie is the only one in her family who has a business. She owns a small business selling various products such as cosmetic products, juice, water, and so on. This business is profitable in the region where it is located and this is her 4th successful year in operation.

Leatitie is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more drinks to sell. With this loan she will be able to satisfy the demands of her customers and, with this satisfaction, she hopes to earn more money from the additional products in her shop. With the extra money, Leatitie will be able to save money for the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more drinks to sell

loans.name: Pet

texts.en:
Pet S., 28, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. 

She sells groceries for an income of about $1.60 USD per day. Her husband operates his truck to provide transportation services for workers at a garment factory, earning an income of $6.60 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of $500 USD to purchase more groceries to stock the store.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand on her poultry project

loans.name: Arc-En-Ciel Plus Group

texts.en:
Barli is the leader of a community bank named “Arc-En-Ciel Plus”, which means “Rainbow” in English and is composed of 23 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses.

Barli is 44 years old and the father of five children ages 3 to 16. Three of them attend school. 

Barli runs a service of charging batteries. He has been a micro-entrepreneur since 1985. He runs his business in the Middle Eastern area of Kinshasa. 

He is working hard because his ambition is to become an excellent battery charger service in his area. The loan he’ll obtain next will be used to buy 50 liters of battery acid and some accessories for his service with the aim of increasing the profits. 

Since he wants to develop and diversify his business, he decided to join one of Hope’s groups in October 2009. Currently, he makes a profit of about $180 per week. Barli has succeeded with good strategies to build up permanent customers. He always talks with his customers, he knows them well by their names, and he never runs out of stock.

loans.use: To purchase 50 liters of battery acid to resell with the aim of generating the profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Togos

texts.en:
Togos B. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and 15-year-old daughter in an apartment in Tuv province, Mongolia. Her daughter, Tuvshinzaya, attends a local secondary school. Her husband operates a transportation business between Zuunmod and Ulaanbaatar. 

During the day, Togos operates a meat retailing business at a local meat market. She has been operating her business since 1992, and has steadily expanded her business over the past 18 years. With her business profits, she was able to pay her two children's university tuition fees until they graduated. They have been living separately from their parents. 

Togos is an honest and hardworking person who has been working hard to improve her family's quality of life. She has a goal to operate a supermarket in the future. Togos is requesting a 4,000,000 Mongolian Tugrug (MNT) loan to purchase large amount of meat at wholesale prices to resell to her many customers for a profit.

loans.use: to buy meat at wholesale for resale at retail

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 36 years old and married with 4 children aged between 1 to 13. Two of the children are currently attending school.

Bernard is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. He has been farming for 10 years and has one employee. His main product is milk which he sells to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries. His main challenge is the high cost of artificial insemination and lack of enough feed. 

He is also a cash crop farmer and sells his tea to the Kenya Tea Development Authority factory in Kapkatet town in Rift Valley Kenya. Before venturing into farming, he was operating a retail shop in the same area. 

He successfully completed a previous loan for 45,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan for 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase the production of milk, allowing more sales and income. The extra income from this loan will help meet the family expenses. In future he would like to increase the number of his dairy cows from the current 3 to 6 dairy cows.

He is grateful to Juhudi for making the funds available to them and requests to be funded more once they clear their current loans.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Ilhombek

texts.ru: Саъдуллоев Ильхомбек проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Более 10 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Он в основном продает мужскую одежду и обувь. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Ilhombek S. lives in the Khuroson district. He is 36 years old, married and has 5 children. He has a secondary education and has been involved in retail sales at a market for over 10 years. Ilhombek primarily sells men's clothing and shoes. He is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 35, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells silk products for an income of about USD 3.3 per day. Her husband is employed as a farm tractor operator, earning an income of USD 4.6 per day to help cover the family expenses. Sao is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more silk for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her family's house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy silk products for resale.

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared is 24 years old. He is a married father of 3 children, twins aged 6 years and a 2 year old. Two of his children are currently attending school. Jared is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya, and he has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years. His main produce are bananas and tea, which he sells to the local market and to the Kenya Tea Development Authority, respectively. Jared's main challenge is poor transportation, which makes it hard to access the market.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.30,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and they will also have enough milk for domestic consumption. In the future, Jared would like to acquire 3 more dairy cows and sell at least 60 litres of milk per day. He is grateful to Juhudi for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mêlé Péla

texts.en: Madame Mêlé Péla A. is 31 years old and owns a second hand clothing shop in Lomé, Togo. She is single and has one child. Madame A. has been selling second hand clothing since 2008. She has already taken out two loans from WAGES, and has requested a third loan of 300,000 CFA to purchase more merchandise for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Zakiya

texts.en:
Zakiya Q. is a 52-year-old housewife and the mother of four daughters and three sons. Three of her daughters are married. Her three sons are also married and live with their wives in the family's house. The eldest son is a school bus driver, the second is a taxi driver, and the youngest is a Palestinian National Authority employee.

Zakiya's family owns land in Jenin, so she decided to start a business where her husband and family work together and make a living, since they are a big family and need a better income.

Zakiya decided to raise chickens on their land, so she took a $1500 loan from FATEN to purchase coops, chicken, feed, and other items that are required to start the business.

Zakiya's son, Omar, who will be helping his mother in this business, appears in the picture, because Zakiya is not comfortable having her picture published.

loans.use: Start a poultry farm

loans.name: Annonciatha

texts.en:
Annonciatha is the 58-year-old married mother of six children who are between the ages of 10 and 28, some of them in school.

Annonciatha owns a small shop which sells different kinds of products such as juice, cosmetics products, water, and so on. She has been engaged in her business for over three years. Her small shop is open from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except Sunday.

Annonciatha is now requesting her loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products for her shop. These additional products will allow her to attract more customers which will help her to earn more profits. With these profits she expects to save money for the future of her family. Particularly, her children who are in school will get their school fees paid more easily.

loans.use: To purchase more products for her shop to expand her business

loans.name: Nem

texts.en: Nem M., 47, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries for an income of about USD 1 per day. Her husband is employed as a construction worker and an undertaker, earning an income of USD 2.6 per day to help cover the family expenses.  M. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more supplements for her husband’s cremation business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her family's home. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more supplements to aid the undertaking business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 51 years old. She is a married mother of 5 children between the ages of 20 and 28. Two of the children are currently attending school. Jane is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for 20 years. Her main produce is maize, beans and bananas which she sells to the local market and to other institutions, such as schools. Her main challenges in farming are poor market prices and the constant climatic changes, which affect production.

Jane has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the living standards of her family. She aspires to be the largest producer of milk and crops in the region. She appreciates the help given by Juhudi and hopes to have more financing in the future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Chun C., 37, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She produces cow ties and raises animals for an income of about USD 2 per day.

Her husband is a tuk-tuk driver, earning an income of USD 6.6 per day to help cover the family expenses.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family to use.

loans.name: Chok

texts.en:
Chok O., 30, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries for an income of about USD 1.2 per day.

Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.

O. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Madame Fati B. is 57 years old and was born in Assoli, Togo. She sells charcoal and firewood out of her home in Lomé. Fati and her husband have five children. He works for the military.

Madame B. has requested a loan of 400,000 CFA to purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell. This is her first time working with WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 29 years old. He is married with three children aged 1½ to 7 years old. Two of his children currently attend school.

He is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practicing farming for the last 10 years. Besides farming, he also draws income from carpentry and masonry. His main challenges are lack of water and a ready market for the milk.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 35000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The additional income from this investment will enable him to educate his children and meet family needs. In the future Charles intends to have four more dairy cows and improve his farming activities.

He says he has managed to acquire a dairy cow which he could not manage before, and in the future he is thinking that Juhudi will help him add more products.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Séna Akouété

texts.en:
Monsieur Séna D. sells construction materials in the Nukafu quarter of Lomé, Togo. He is 37 years old and married to a school teacher. They have one child.

Séna sells paint, tools, and other construction materials. He is taking his first microloan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA to reinforce his sales.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies.

loans.name: Kanemu Development Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
S. Musa has been an enterprising retail businessman for the past five years. He has been mostly selling essential household retail merchandise like sugar, salt, fruit and soap. He plies his business in Kibibi, Mpigi. He also ekes out side profits from a small poultry business that he began two years ago.

In the course of the last five years, Musa has built up his experience track record which has, on several occasions, called for fortitude in the face of financial adversity. His persistence has always been his calling card, however, and it is what lies behind his business’s longevity.

Musa is on the sunny side of 20 with no wife or children. This has, in a way, played into his hands, being that he has major responsibilities to shoulder. His determination to succeed at this stage is so high. With this loan, he envisages better prospects in the running of his business. He principally wants to revamp his retail shop with more goods like bags of sugar and salt.

loans.use: To purchase bags of general retail items like sugar, soap, salt, fresh fruits, matches, etc.

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus is 33 years old, married and has six children, all attending school, between the ages of 4 and 14 years old. A farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya, Nicodemus has been practising mixed farming for over 10 years. He sells his main produce of sugarcane, bananas, tea and milk to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenges in farming are insufficient capital and poor market prices.

Nicodemus is requesting this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income arising from this loan will help him pay the school fees for his children and start a small business. In the future he would like to acquire three more dairy cows to improve his production and sale of milk.

He is grateful to Juhudi for its support.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es:
El señor Emilio Rodríguez tiene 25 años y está casado por más de 5 años con la señora Ivana Medrano Mamani,  tienen 2 hijos pequeños los cuales acuden a una escuelita de la zona por las mañanas. Emilio vive en la Zona conocida como Zofraco en el barrio Monte Canto en Cochabamba, donde tiene vacas, cuya leche vende a una empresa que se encarga de elaborar diferentes productos lácteos.

Emilio es una persona joven que quiere incrementar poco a poco la cantidad de ganado lechero que tiene y de esa manera poder incrementar su producción de leche cruda aun mas. Emilio espera poder obtener este préstamo para poder comprar una vaca lechera y aumentar su producción de leche y así sus ingresos, y agradece mucho a la gente que por medio se kiva le puede dar la oportunidad de superarse.

Emilio nos cuenta que en un futuro quisiera sacar un nuevo préstamo para poder construir su casita en el terreno que su padre le dejo como herencia hace unos años. De esa manera poder darle a su esposa e hijos una mejor vida.
texts.en:
Emilio R. is 25 years old and has been married to Ivana Medrano Mamani for the past five years. They have two small children who go to a neighborhood preschool in the mornings. Emilio lives in the Zofraco part of the Monte Carlo neighborhood, Cochabamba, where they have dairy cows that produce milk to sell to businesses that make dairy products. Emilio is a young man that would like to slowly increase his number of dairy cows to increase his milk production even more. Emilio hopes to receive this loan so that he can buy another dairy cow, growing his milk production and his profits. He appreciates the people from Kiva who have given him this opportunity. Emilio says that in the future he would like to apply for another loan so that he can build a small house in the countryside on the land he inherited from his father some years ago. In this way, he can provide a better life for his wife and children.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Heyd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase dairy cattle

loans.name: Bukari Twimukye, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
A business selling produce is in much favor by many people here in Uganda and this is where one K. Hope has banked her savings to earn more profit.

The 30-year-old mother of three started up her grocery store dealing in dry foods, especially cereals, two years ago in Kashenshero, Bushenyi. Due to her hard work and determination, she has been able to run this business and it earns her 75,000 Ugandan shillings monthly.

With this loan, Hope is looking forward to restocking her business which will improve it in the market and also attract many customers to her shop. Earning more revenue and making her business expand is her motive in this case so as to live a self-sustaining life for herself and her family.

loans.use: To restock her business with produce like dried cassava and maize

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 56 years old and married with 8 children between 17 and 35 years old. Four of his children are currently attending school. Alfred is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. For the last 20 years he has grown maize, beans, millet and vegetables which he sells at the local market. He also gets extra income from selling tea leaves to the Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenges are poor transportation and lack of a market for his products. 

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes.30,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and sale. In five years time, he hopes to greatly improve his financial status and have at least four high-yielding dairy cows that produce more than 15 litres of milk each per day.

He is grateful to Juhudi for the financial support and asks for further support in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Warumi Group

texts.en:
Meet Bahati K. and the Warumi Group. Bahati is 29 years old and married with two children, an 11 year-old son and a 7 year-old daughter. She also supports her 19 year-old sister who is in high school.  Bahati has been running a small shop for two years and it is doing quite well. She has two employees, and the business is open daily from 7 am until midnight.  She earns about $700 in profit.  She has already repaid one loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, and used it to purchase drinks, chips, and other inventory items for her shop.  Bahati will use this loan to restock beer, spirits, and soda at her shop, since these sell quickly. As her profits increase, Bahati plans to move her shop from its current rented space into a new location that she owns, and also to build a new home for her family.

Bahati is a member of the Warumi Group, whose 18 members run a variety of businesses including selling eggs, chicken, fuel and food. Members hold each other accountable for repaying the loan. Bahati is in the back of the photo, raising her hand.

loans.use: Restocking alcohol, beer and soda for sale at her general store.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is married with three children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Harriet is a tailor in Bwaise, one of the city suburbs. Harriet has been in this business for over 15 years. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials from Kiyembe, one of the busiest places in Kampala city where clothing materials are sold.  She uses public transport to and from shopping and goes shopping once a week. Besides this tailoring business, she also sells second hand clothes at the very shop where she does her tailoring.  Her customers are mainly women and school girls.  She works six days a week. She rents her business premises at 30,000/= per month.  Her business challenge included transportation of clothing materials from Kiyembe to her shop in Bwaise.  She aspires to own a plot of land.  Harriet joined MCDT because it was giving out timely loans with low interest rates.  Harriet resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she stays with seven people. The family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent for both residence and business, school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Keki Group

texts.en:
This is Abed A. and the Keki loan group of Tujijenge Tanzania. The group's name is "Keki" — the Kiswahili word for "cake"!  Many words in Kiswahili have been borrowed from English and the spelling is changed to reflect the Tanzanian pronunciation. 

Abed is 30 years old and married with one son who is a year and eight months old. He also supports his younger brother, who is 18 years old and in high school. Abed has run a small duka (shop) and juice stand for the past year and a half.  He works each day from 6:30 am until 10 pm and makes a monthly profit of around $140(200,000 Tanzanian shillings). Abed fully repaid his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he used to improve the juice stand at his shop. He will use this loan to purchase a refrigerator and increase his shop's stock.  

Abed will use some of his profits to cover household expenses, and will reinvest the remainder in his business. He dreams of growing his business to include an expanded general store, as well as a café with tea, coffee, milk, chapati and other foods for sale.  

Abed is the Secretary of his group, whose 20 members run a variety of businesses including selling food, charcoal, fish and cosmetics.  Members hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, Abed is standing at the back wearing a red T-shirt.

loans.use: Buying a refrigerator and increasing inventory

loans.name: Zambarau Group

texts.en:
Meet Hawa S. and the Zambarau Group. Hawa is 27 years old and married with a two-year-old son. She also supports her 19 year-old sister, and they work together at Hawa's shop. She has been running the business for two years and it is going well. The shop is open from 7 am until 8:30 pm daily, and Hawa earns a profit of about $115 (160,000 Tsh) per month. This will be Hawa's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, and she will use it to purchase additional inventory of sugar, rice and beans, which sell the fastest at her shop. Hawa will use the profits from this loan to purchase more stock and expand her inventory. She dreams of growing the business and eventually adding a beauty saloon.  

Hawa is the treasurer of her group, Zambarau. At Tujijenge Tanzania, the groups name themselves, and Zambarahau is the name of a local fruit. The group's 18 members run a variety of businesses including selling clothes, food, meat and motorcycle maintenance.  Members hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.  

Hawa is in the middle of the photo, wearing an orange dress with a white scarf.

loans.use: buying supplies of sugar, rice and beans.

loans.name: Mona

texts.en: Mona is a 37-year-old woman and the mother of four children. Since 1994 she has produced thyme, olives and olive oil, dry yogurt for Lebanese pizzas, lentils and pickles. Mona requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to improve her business and to purchase merchandise. This is her second loan having repaid the first on time. She offers good quality and very tasty products. Her clients are people from her region — mainly her friends, neighbors and occasionally tourists. Mona decided on her business because she is a very good cook and has experience. She says that she has a talent for cooking and loves her work. She plans to keep on improving her business as well as her financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Mabatini Group

texts.en:
Meet Ramadhani O. and the Mabitini Group. Ramadhani is 45 years old, divorced, and the father of five sons who are between two and 22 years old. His eldest three children go to school.

Ramadhani has been running a fish selling business for 15 years. He buys fish each morning and sells fresh fish and fried fish at two locations. He works every day from 8 am until late at night, and earns about $570 each month.

He has used two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand his business and repaid them both successfully. Ramadhani will use this loan to open a third location for selling fish and to buy a small boat which will provide added products each day. Ramadhani will use any extra profits to cover household expenses and school fees for his children. He hopes to continue supporting his children through school, and eventually to buy a car.

Ramadhani is the President of his group and this will be his first Motisha loan. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. The 6 group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

Ramadhani is wearing a blue shirt in the picture.

loans.use: To start a new location for fish sales.

loans.name: Mitema Group

texts.en:
Meet Amina M. and the Mitema Group. Amina is 47 years old, married and has four grown children. Her fifth child died giving birth last year, and Amina also cares for her three young grand-children who are 12 years, 3 years and 10 months old.

Amina runs a business going door-to-door selling traditional African fabrics called khanga and vitenge. In the late afternoons she also sells firewood at a small stand. Amina starts work around 11am, after taking care of her grandchildren. She works until about 6 pm each day and earns a profit of about 75000 TSH ($50) per month.

This is Amina's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use it to buy additional khanga and vitenge for her fabric sales, and extra firewood for her stand. Any profit from this loan will go to support school-fees for her eldest grandchild, milk for the younger kids, and general household expenses.

Amina hopes that as her business grows she will be able to stop selling firewood and focus exclusively on fabric sales. She wants to buy a permanent shop for her business instead of selling door to door. She would also like to purchase fabrics from other countries in the region including Malawi and Zambia.

Amina is the Assistant Treasurer of the Mitema Group. The group's 17 members run a variety of businesses including selling fabrics, food, and chickens. The group's members hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, Amina is in the middle with her arm raised.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is 65 years old. He is married with six children between 19 and 38 years old. One of his children currently attends school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for over 25 years. He mainly produces bananas, tea, and milk which he sells to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenge is lack of enough skills in dairy farming.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The loan will enable him to acquire a good dairy cow that will produce enough milk for family consumption and sale. The extra income will also enable him to pay school fees for his children. In the future he would like to start his own business and own 3 quality dairy cows for milk production.

He is asking for Juhudi to continue supporting him financially and to train him on modern skills in dairy farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is married with six children and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members .  Hadjah owns a food stall in Kitawuluzi selling all types of foodstuffs. Hadjah has been doing this business for over 10 years. She wants to use this loan  to buy more foodstuffs like bananas, irish potatoes, cassava, onions, oranges and tomatoes. Hadjah uses public transport to and from shopping. She buys these foodstuffs from Owino market and goes shopping three times a week. Her major customers are the community around her shop. Hadjah works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include seasonality and transportation of foodstuffs from Owino to her stall.  She aspires to get enough profit to build her own house and to start going directly to the  farmers to buy her products.  She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bananas, irish potatoes, cassava, onions and oranges

loans.name: Yuventius

texts.en:
Yuventius is 68 years old. He is married and has 7 children aged between 22 to 33 years old. Two of the children attend school.

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 40 years. His main produce is bananas, coffee, and tea which he sells to the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority in Kisii town. His main challenge in farming is poor infrastructure that hinders him from accessing the market easily.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES 45000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and sale. In future, he would like to acquire two more dairy cows to increase the production of milk.

He hopes to continue getting financial support and advice from Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
Este comité se encuentra en pleno desarrollo de las capacitaciones  y trabajando cada una en sus actividades dentro del 2° ciclo del programa del Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya.
Ellas comentan que tienen mucha esperanza en que con el trabajo y buen manejo del crédito lograran salir adelante de la mejor manera posible brindando cada una a sus hijos todas las comodidades y con una buena educación.  
Una de las integrantes es la  señora Estela Cáceres quien se dedica a la realización y venta de zapatillas bordadas y de zapatos.
Ella compra las zapatillas y los accesorios para bordar como, lentejuelas, canutillos, y hilos de colores.
La zapatillas son bordadas de acuerdo a los pedidos que ella recibe ya tiene en cuenta que el color y los diseños que desean los clientes.
El crédito solicitado por ella es para la compra de zapatillas y zapato para vender y accesorios.
texts.en:
This group is in the midst of a training program that is in full swing, and is working on each of their activities within their 2nd loan cycle with the "Committee of Enterprising Women" of the Fundación Paraguaya. They comment that they are very hopeful that with work and sound credit management, they will manage to get ahead in the best way possible, providing each of their children with all of the creature comforts and a good education. One of the members is Señora Estela Cáceres, who makes and sells embroidered slippers and shoes. She buys the slippers and the accessories to embroider with, such as: sequins, beads, and colored threads. The slippers are embroidered according to the orders that she gets, since she takes into account the color and designs that the customers want. The loan requested for her is to buy slippers and shoes to sell, and accessories.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy slippers, shoes, sequins, colored thread and other accessories to embroider

loans.name: Santa Rosa De Chontacancha Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Santa Rosa D. Chontacancha está ubicado en L. comunidad D. Chontacancha, en el departamento D. Huancavelica, inicia su 1er ciclo con 14 socias.

Gregoria, es casada y tiene 3 hijos D. 12,14 y 17 años, se dedica a L. venta D. cereales y abarrotes, inició su negocio hace 10 años, en esa época elL. era L. única que vendía ahora hay mucha competencia en su comunidad, es por ello que ahora Gregoria lleva su mercadería a otras comunidades cercanas como Lircay. El préstamo que va a recibir le servirá para comprar cereales al por mayor y bebidas por cajas. El sueño D. Gregoria es tener una tienda bien granD. llena D. mercadería, elL. sabe que lo logrará.

Francisca, es casada y tiene 3 hijos D. 14, 18 y 20 años, se dedica a L. venta D. quesillo y helados, inició su negocio adquiriendo una congeladora para L. preparación D. chupetes y helados para vender en las escuelas y fiestas D. su comunidad, Francisca quiere cambiar D. negocio y por ello con el préstamo que va a recibir invertirá en L. compra D. animales para criar y vender, aumentando así su capital. Su sueño es llevar sus helados a otras comunidades y a L. vez preparar yogurt D. frutas.
texts.en:
The Santa Rosa D. Chontacancha Communal Bank is located in the Chontacancha community, in the state of Huancavelica. They began their first cycle with 14 members. Gregoria is married and has three children, ages 12, 14, and 17. She sells grains and groceries. 10 years ago, when she first began her business, she was the only one that sold these products in her community, but now there is a lot of competition. As a result, Gregoria now sells her merchandise in neighboring communities, such as Lircay. The loan that she is seeking would help her purchase grains in bulk and boxes of refreshments. Gregoria's dream is to have a large store full of merchandise. She believes that she can achieve it. Francisca is married and has 3 children, ages 14, 18, and 20. She sells cheese and ice-cream. She started her business by buying a freezer and making popsicles and ice-cream to sell at schools and local festivals. Francisca wants to change her business and plans to invest her future loan in the purchase of animals to raise and sell, thus increasing her capital. Her dream is to sell her ice-cream in other communities and at the same time prepare fruit yogurts.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains in bulk and refreshments.

loans.name: Bwavumpologoma Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
K. Charles is an affable and ambitious 37-year-old married father of one. He is a man with a business sense of purpose. To take care of his family, he knew he had to find a reliable means of subsistence. It is exactly five years ago that he made a decision to begin his small clinic and drugstore enterprise in Kiyoola, Lugazi.

Ever since then, Charles has made steady headway in firmly taking measures aimed at growing and expanding his franchise. Coming to terms with the fact that his neighborhood did not have a clinic, made him seize the opportunity to open up one. This business has been of paramount importance to him, especially in regard to the improvement in the welfare standing of his family.

In a week, Charles’ business generates him profits totaling up to 70,000 shillings. With this loan, he wants to buy a new consignments of drugs for his clinic and drugstore.

loans.use: To purchase a new consignments of drugs for his clinic and drugstore

loans.name: Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Maiya L. lives in Khokhana-Dobato, Lalitpur. She is married and has a son and a daughter. Her son is studying in grade 11 and daughter in grade 7.

She is a farmer in Khokhana-Dobato and grows different types of vegetables. Due to the lack of technology most of the farmers in this area depend on seasonal farming.

Mrs. L. sells her vegetables in the local vegetable market in the mornings and evenings. Now she is requesting a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her work.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha R. is a hard-working, ambitious woman from Beit Sahour, a city near Beit Lehem. Maha is married and the mother of two sons. Maha takes care of her household, her sons, and her old and sick parents-in-law. Therefore she decided to start a business where she could be close to her parents-in-law. Maha built a floor on top of her parents-in-law's house and opened a sewing workshop.

Maha used her husband's savings to start the business in one of the rooms in her house. Then, she came to FATEN to take a $3000 loan to continue preparing the workshop.

Maha started this business to support her family, because her husband makes only $400 a month, and to improve her house, since it still needs improvements. Now she has a good number of clients and needs to have a bigger space for her work.

In the photograph, Maha appears in her workshop.

loans.use: To improve her sewing workshop

loans.name: Kubencha

texts.en:
Kubencha is 75 years old. He is married with seven children between the ages of 20 and 40 years old. One of his children is currently attending school. 

He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for over 30 years. His main produce is bananas, tea and sugarcane, which he sells to the local market and to the Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenges are a lack of business start-up capital and a lack of dairy-farming skills.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo, a Kiva partner, for 35,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will help him acquire a good dairy cow that will produce enough milk for consumption and sale. In five years, he hopes to have two quality dairy cows that produce at least 15 liters of milk daily.

He is grateful to Juhudi for providing him with a loan.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Mrs. Sani Tamanag lives in Khokhana-Dobato, Lalitpur. She has four members, including herself, in her family. She is a farmer in Khokhana-Dobato and she grows different types of vegetables. Due to the lack of technology, most of the farmers in this area depend on seasonal farming.

Mrs. T. sells her vegetables in the local vegetable market in the mornings and evenings. Now she is requesting a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her work. She has a son and a daughter. Her son is studying in university and her daughter is studying in grade 11.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and has one child. The child goes to school.  Mary also takes care of additional family members. She is a tailor and decorator in Makerere, one of the Kampala suburbs. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials and decorations.  Mary uses public transport to and from shopping. She buys these materials from Kiyembe. She has been in this business for 15 years.  She rents her business premises at 30,000/= per month. Mary works six days a week. Her business challenges are thieves, seasonality and license fees.  She aspires to build a tailoring school.   Mary receives an average of six customers  per day. She makes fashions according to her customer's need. She decided to work with MCDT because it was near her home. Mary resides in and owns a two room-house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses are medication and food.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Nauti

texts.en:
Mrs. Nauti S. is a grocery storekeeper in the village of Bhatkepati, Lalitpur. She opened her grocery shop in her own house to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She sells grocery goods like rice, maize, noodles, etc., in her shop. Now, due to the increasing demand for grocery goods, she is requesting a loan to invest in her shop to buy different varieties of grocery goods. 

Mrs. Nauti lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her husband is a carpenter. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 4 and her daughter studies in grade 8.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Hira

texts.en:
Hira R. lives with her husband, Mr. Goam Bahadur R., and one son in Sanepa, Lalitpur. Her husband is a house painter. Her son is studying in grade 4. Most of the people in this region are involved in running small businesses like grocery stores. 

Mrs. R. opened her small cafe 4 years ago to strengthen the economic situation of her family. She sells different varieties of food items in her little cafe, and her specialty is Nepali food such as DalBhat (rice). She also sells tea and coffee. Her cafe is small but very popular in her locality. Mrs. R. is requesting this loan to buy necessary food ingredients for her cafe.

loans.use: to buy necessary ingredients for her cafe

loans.name: Mochama

texts.en:
Mochama is 61 years old and married, with 7 children aged between 26 and 40 years old. One of his children is currently attending school. 

He is a farmer from the area near Kisii town in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last 30 years. His main products are milk, maize, beans and millet, which he sells to the local market. He also produces tea, which he sells to the Kenya Tea Development Authority. His main challenges are lack of farming equipment, transportation problems and lack of training in dairy farming and animal husbandry. 

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo/Kiva for 30,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will enable him to cater to his family's needs. In the future, he hopes to expand his dairy farming and acquire high yielding dairy cows. 

He appreciates the work done by Juhudi/Kiva and looks forward to more assistance. He is asking Juhudi to include training on dairy husbandry in their program.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Committed Women's Group, Kampala

texts.en:
She found herself in at a loose end after the death of her husband, but 34-year-old resourceful and unfazed N. Zaituni knew she had to quickly come to grips with the harsh realities that lay ahead of her if she was to significantly manage the responsibility of taking care of her four children and ten orphans.

After overcoming the grief that came in the wake of the untimely death of her husband, Zaituni embarked on a business venture she envisaged would help her shoulder her late husband’s responsibilities – she began a restaurant business along Buganda Road in Kampala city. On the grounds of her resilience, determination and diligence, her business has now lasted fifteen years.

Zaituni’s odds of further future success are more than 10 to 1, owing to the semblance of high customer interest in her restaurant. In a month, she says she makes profits in the range of 200 to 250 thousand shillings.

With this loan, Zaituni wants to buy more furniture like chairs, tables and cutlery for her expanding restaurant business.

loans.use: To purchase new furniture and utensils for her restaurant

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en: Barbara is a single mother of two children and one of her children goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a stall at her home selling second hand clothes. She wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothes.  She has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for two weeks, servicing her first loan.  Barbara doesn’t have any other side business. At times she moves door-to-door selling her clothes.  She sells to all categories of people but at retail only.  Barbara works six days week. She buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and uses public transport to and from shopping. Barbara goes shopping once a week. Her business challenge is the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her and even makes it hard for her to walk around looking for customers.  She aspires to start buying a full bale of second hand clothes.  She joined MCDT because she wanted to raise capital for her business.  She resides in and owns a one-room house and the family has access to electricty and piped water .

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se formó gracias a  las ganas que tienen las integrantes para trabajar en grupo y ayudarse de alguna manera para seguir progresando, ella se encuentran en plena actividad dentro del octavo ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
La venta de comestibles es una actividad que realiza muchas mujeres en Paraguay entre ella se encuentra la señora Ramona quien prepara alimentos de diversos tipos para vender.
La venta de sus comestibles lo realiza en forma ambulante recorriendo las zonas concurridas como plazas, mercados y otros, y de esa manera ella vende los productos que prepara cada día.
Su desea es contar con un puesto de venta dentro del mercado para tener un lugar definido para trabajar, pero asegura que en unos meses trabajando mucho logrará su objetivo.
En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de ingredientes como carne, harina de maíz, fideos, panificados y otros.
texts.en:
This group got together thanks to a shared desire to work in a group and help each other to get ahead. Their activities are in full swing in their 8th loan cycle with the "Committee of Enterprising Women" program. Many women in Paraguay have a business selling food, among them is Señora Ramona, who makes a variety of types of food to sell. She is a street vendor who sells the food that she makes in the busiest areas such as plazas, markets and other areas. In this way she sells the products that she makes each day. Her desire is to have a stall inside the market so she can have a defined place to work, but she assures us that with a few months of hard work she will achieve this objective. At this time she is requesting a loan to buy ingredients such as meat, corn meal, noodles, bread and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as: meat, cooking oil, corn meal, noodles and plates to serve the food

loans.name: Oxiacaque Group

texts.es:
El grupo “Oxiacaque”  nombrado así por que son originarias del  Poblado del mismo nombre. Esta integrado por seis mujeres. Los representa doña Patricia U. C., tiene 1 hijo, su esposo es electricista, con el crédito comprara cables, focos, contactos, probador D. luz, pinzas, cintas.  Todos los hijos D. Doña Aniceta están casados, su actividad es L. venta D. comida que lleva a ofrecer a los empleados D. compañías que se ubican en ese poblado, L. señorita Edita  tiene una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes en su domicilio, doña  Isidra  tienen 2 hijos, se dedica  a L. venta D. pescado en su domicilio, doña Margarita y María Jesús  se dedican a L. cría D. cerdos para su posterior matanza y venta D. carne, doña Margarita tiene 3 hijos y María Jesús ninguno.  


Doña Chucha como así L. conocen en su comunidad, comprará cerdo, alimento, vitaminas, su esposo es quien se encarga D. matar  y salir a ofrecer L. carne por su comunidad que también venD. chicharrones, longaniza, manteca. Su meta es que sus hijos tengan mejor nivel D. vida y poner un local D. carnicería en su comunidad y comunidades vecinas. 

Todas son muy alegres y están  contentas D. que se les pueda dar un apoyo para hacer crecer  sus actividades económicas, 4 tienen actividades diferentes y 2 son parecidas, es un grupo solidario.

Están muy agradecidas por el apoyo que le brinda L. Fundación y KIVA al tomarlas en cuenta para otorgarles un financiamiento y hacer que sus negocios tengan éxito
texts.en:
The“Oxiacaque” group is called that because they are from the town of the same name. It is maD. up of six women. They are represented by Patricia U. C.. She has 1 child and her husband is an electrician. She will buy cables, lightbulbs, contacts, electricity tester, pliers and tape. All of Aniceta's children are married. Her activity is selling food that she offers the employees of companies in town. Edita has a little grocery store in her home. Isidra has 2 children, and she sells fish from her home. Margarita and Maria Jesus raise pigs for slaughter and sell meat. Margarita has 3 children and Maria Jesus has none. Chucha, as she is known in her community, will buy pigs, feed, and vitamins. Her husband is the one who is in charge of slaughtering and selling the meat in the community. He also sells pork rinds, longaniza, and lard. Her goal is for her children to have a better quality of life and to have a butcher shop in her community and in neighboring communities. All of them are very cheerful and they are happy that they are able to have the support to grow their economic activities. 4 of the activities are different and 2 are similar. It is a supportive group. They are very grateful for the support offered by the foundation and KIVA for considering them when granting them financing and making their businesses successful.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pigs, fish, knives, feed, vitamins, chicken, meat, tomatoes, onions, peppers, disposable cups and plates, cables, lightbulbs, contacts, electricity tester, pliers, electrical tape.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, aged 43, is the mother of four. She lives in her own house in Hoima, Uganda, which accommodates her family. She operates a restaurant from which she sustains the welfare of her family of five people.

Evelyn, like many parents and guardians in Uganda, faces the daunting task of looking for school fees for her children when the new school term is about to begin. In most cases, people do not have sufficient cash to facilitate payment of the fees. Evelyn will use the loan funds to pay school fees for her son, Wilbert, who is in high school.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her son who is in high school

loans.name: Krishna

texts.en:
Mrs. Krishna M. is a resident of Sanepa, which is one of the busiest cities in the lalitpur district. Most of the people in the region are involved in small businesses like grocery stores.

Mrs. Krisnha M. lives with her husband and three children, two daughters and one son. Her daughters are in grades 9 and 10 and her son is in grade 6. A few years ago, Mrs. M. opened her vegetable shop in Sanepa to improve her family's economic condition and to provide better education for her children. She sells different kinds of vegetables such as potatoes, tomatoes, green vegetables, etc. Due to the increasing demand for vegetables in her area, she is requesting a loan to invest in her shop.

loans.use: to buy vegetables

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz, a resident of Borewala (famous for its shrines) Pakistan, owns a small, two-roomed house and has been living in it with her family for over twenty years. She is a very talented and hardworking lady. She operates a clothes-sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. She sews clothes for her neighbors and charges them  PKR100 for simple stitching and PKR150 for stitching designer suits. She sews two suits in every day and usually generates an income of almost PKR 300 daily. She uses half of her money to purchase kitchen items and she saves the other half for a rainy day. She has good managing skills. She not only works for the betterment of her family but also takes care of their health as well. She handles the domestic chores and cooks food for them. 

Her husband is involved in an animal selling business. He purchases the animals from the animal market and sells them to his customers. He also loves to take care of the animals. When the animals are fully grown, he sells them to the animal market and generates income. He has been in this profession for the last ten years. 

Shahnaz is applying for a loan from Asasah. She will invest the capital in her husband’s business so that he can purchase the animals (goats) and increase the profit of his business.

loans.use: To purchase animals to sell.

loans.name: Fenix De Fuego Group

texts.es:
Fénix de Fuego es un grupo integrado por dos mujeres y dos hombres ellos están ubicados en la Av. Alfredo del Mazo Colonia Santa Cruz en la comunidad de Valle de Chalco Estado de México. Todos se sienten muy a gusto en el grupo hasta ahora ya que se conocen y la comunicación que tienen es buena. 

La señora Alejandra B. L. es la representante del grupo tiene 40 años, estudió hasta el nivel medio superior, su esposo trabaja de chofer y tiene dos hijos, una mujer y un varón los cuales estudian la primaria y la secundaria.
